newsitem.title: USA: Oracle unveils server clustering software.
newsitem.headline: Oracle unveils server clustering software.

text.p: Oracle Corp on Monday unveiled software that ties together several cheap server computers running Windows NT into essentially one computer, significantly speeding up the management of big databases.

The software gives Oracle, the biggest publisher of database software, a crucial lead of several months over rival Microsoft Corp in high-end databases, analysts said. Microsoft has stepped up its efforts to chase after Oracle's database software business in the past two years.
Oracle unveiled Oracle Parallel Server for Windows NT, a program that ties together, or "clusters," up to four Windows NT servers.
Each of the servers manages a part of one big database. Because each machine has to do less work, the cluster can store and retrieve information from a database much faster than a single machine.

Oracle also announced Oracle Fail Safe, a program that makes sure that if a server malfunctions, another server will take its place and handle its duties until the malfuntioning server is fixed by a technician.
Both products will be shipping within 30 days, the company said.
With the release, Oracle would be months ahead of Microsoft with clustering and fail-safe capabilities, said Peter Kastner, analyst at market researcher Aberdeen Group Inc in Boston.
The products should be a relief to companies that have considered basing their information management systems on Windows NT, Kastner said.
